A citizen science website has been created to allow people to track butterfly species around them and contribute to research by using these observations. However, correctly identifying butterfly species is a challenging task for non-experts, and currently, it requires the involvement of entomologists to verify the labels of novice users on the website. We have developed a computer vision model to label butterfly images from eButterfly automatically, reducing the need for human experts. Our model incorporates geographic and temporal information of where and when the image was taken, in addition to the image itself. We demonstrate that we can successfully apply this spatiotemporal model for fine-grained image recognition, significantly improving the accuracy of our classification model compared to a baseline image recognition system trained on the same dataset.

Introduction

Insect populations are plummeting globally, including butterflies. One of the reasons for this is that butterflies are highly susceptible to changes in their surrounding environment, such as climate change, habitat loss, and pesticide use. Some species of butterflies are directly impacted by climate change through their growth and reproduction cycles, such as the Karner Blue butterfly (Lycaeides melissa samuelis), which is an endangered species. Warmer temperatures can induce butterfly eggs to hatch more quickly while their food source remains dormant, resulting in population decline. Butterflies can also be indirectly impacted by climate change if their habitat becomes altered. For example, the Rocky Mountain Apollo (Parnassius smintheus) and the Monarch (Danaus plexippus) have both incurred ecosystem reduction due to indirect effects of climate change on their host plants.

Apart from the loss of beautiful and culturally meaningful animals, a reduction in butterfly biodiversity could have dire consequences, as butterflies play a key role in a multitude of ecosystems. For instance, butterflies are important pollinators of many species of flowering plants. A reduction in butterfly populations or a change in the timing of butterfly life cycles could mean that certain flower species experience a significant drop in pollination. Butterflies are also an important food source for many animals, including birds, lizards, and other insects. Thus, any changes in butterfly populations can trigger a "butterfly effect" and impact other parts of ecosystems, potentially resulting in far-reaching repercussions.

To understand changes in butterfly populations and employ appropriate conservation measures, it is essential to track the distribution and abundance of butterflies. eButterfly is a website developed by a coalition of researchers across the United States and Canada, where individuals can upload images of butterflies from any location and identify the species to which they belong. Analyzing these butterfly images and the observational data that accompanies them can offer valuable information on changes in geographical and temporal distribution. However, it is crucial to first obtain accurate labels for individual butterfly species. While any user of the eButterfly website can upload an image, they may not necessarily know the species, as fine-grained butterfly identification can be challenging for novice entomologists. We leverage machine learning to automate the labeling process, allowing experts to focus on the most challenging identifications and alleviating a bottleneck that has hindered the eButterfly project.

Related Work

There has been extensive work on using images taken by photographers or camera traps for automatic identification of animal species, including birds, mammals, ground-dwelling insects, bees, and more. Recent work has proposed to improve such image-based identification systems using complementary information, such as spatiotemporal distribution. The motivation behind this is that visually similar species may be present in different geographic regions and at different periods of the year, and therefore knowing where and when a picture was taken may be useful information for fine-grained classification. The authors of [17] developed a spatiotemporal prior that estimates the probability of a species being present based on where and when the image was taken, and applied this model especially to bird identification. However, little work has applied such ideas to the problem of butterfly classification, which to date has been carried out largely based on pure image recognition.
